title: Stockland sees higher settlement numbers next year
text:
But the latest comments, ahead of Monday's AGM, suggest it is now also convinced that the market turnaround - the latest auction figures show Sydney's preliminary clearance rate rose to 84.3 per cent - is feeding through to the first home buyer market that makes up the bulk of the company's buyers.

Stockland also warned that the current tough conditions were likely to persist in retail property this year before improving next year, in part due to a changing mix of tenancies to faster-growing categories.

"We reiterate our expectation that overall retail town centre comparable income will grow moderately through FY20 and improve further in FY21," the company said, as it reported improved sales figures for the September quarter, its first of the FY20 financial year.

“We achieved comparable MAT [moving annual total] growth of 2.6 per cent for the period, including 3.5 per cent growth in majors, driven by the strength in supermarket sales," it said.

"We also achieved comparable specialty sales approximately nine per cent above the Urbis benchmark in the 12 months to 30 September 2019, at $9462 per square metre.

“Over the coming months we will finalise the remaining settlements from $505 million of exchanged non-core retail divestments, and will continue to focus on improving future income resilience by ensuring rents are sustainable; through repositioning and placemaking initiatives; and remixing tenancies to reflect consumer trends around convenience and experience."

Stockland highlighted further steps it had taken to boost its exposure to logistics and industrial property - asset classes that are benefiting from the growth of ecommerce as much as traditional retail is suffering from it. The company announced it had contracted to buy two logistics sites from Fife Group in Brisbane's Carole Park and Richlands.

Advertisement

The company did not disclose the agreed price, but said the two sites had a combined end development value of approximately $140 million on a yield of around 6 per cent and came with an 18 month rent guarantee on any unlet space.

The company also said it struck a further agreement with Fife to consolidate landholdings in western Sydney for a future $500 million, 71-hectare logistics estate. It gave no further details.

“This strategic acquisition will build on the eight existing logistics assets we have in the western Sydney area, positioning us to leverage the investment boom generated by the Western Sydney Airport development,” Mr Steinert said.

Stockland repeated its August predictions of a flat earnings and distributions for the current year.

“Our distribution payout will be at the bottom end of our 75-85 per cent target ratio," it said.
description: As recently as three months ago, Stockland was cutting forecasts, but it still warns of flat earnings and distribution this year.
